questions.question: She …………………. want to be disturbed while she is working.
questions.description: In the simple present tense, we make negatives by putting do not or does not before the infinitive. We use does not when the subject is a singular noun or pronoun.

questions.question: You ………………… returned the camera you borrowed from me.
questions.description: The past participle 'returned' clearly indicates that we need have, not do, here.

questions.question: Michael ………………… speak French.
questions.description: We use ‘does not’ here because Michael is a singular noun.

questions.question: Did you ………………. the parcel last week?
questions.description: After do and does we use the infinitive (first form of the verb). Did + send -> sent

questions.question: They ……………….. the meeting yesterday.
questions.description: The present perfect tense cannot be used with past time expressions.

questions.question: She buys a lot of things she ………………
questions.description: We use does with singular nouns and pronouns. Also, we use the simple present to talk about habits.

questions.question: …………………. you injure yourself while playing football yesterday?
questions.description: The auxiliaries do and have are used in the present tenses.

questions.question: Where could .....................… at this hour of the night?
questions.description: In questions, only the first of the two auxiliaries goes before the subject.

questions.question: ……………… I told you not to be late?
Have you been ………………. for long?
questions.description: In the present perfect continuous tense, we use has/have + been + ing form of the verb.

questions.question: Rahul ………………. the test in the first attempt.
